title: Hackescher Markt
text:
Hackescher Markt ("Hacke's Market") is a square in the central <a href="Mitte%20%28locality%29">Mitte</a> locality of <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, situated at the eastern end of <a href="Oranienburger%20Strasse">Oranienburger Strasse</a>. It is an important <a href="transport%20hub">transport hub</a> and a starting point for the city's <a href="nightlife">nightlife</a>.
Overview.
Originally a marsh north of the city fortifications on the road to <a href="Spandau%20%28locality%29">Spandau</a>, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussian</a> king <a href="Frederick%20the%20Great">Frederick the Great</a> about 1750 had a market square laid out under the surveillance of Townmajor <a href="Hans%20Christoph%20Friedrich%20Graf%20von%20Hacke">Hans Christoph Friedrich Graf von Hacke</a> in the course of a northern town expansion. It was officially named after Hacke on 23 July 1840.
In 1882 the area received access to the <a href="Berlin%20Stadtbahn">Berlin Stadtbahn</a> railway line at <a href="Berlin%20Hackescher%20Markt%20station">Berlin Hackescher Markt station</a>, then called "Börse" after the nearby <a href="Berliner%20B%C3%B6rse">stock exchange</a>. The station was renamed "<a href="Schlo%C3%9Fplatz%20%28Berlin%29">Marx-Engels-Platz</a>" during the <a href="East%20Germany">GDR</a> era.
Formerly a rather neglected area, Hackescher Markt with its old buildings has developed into a cultural and commercial centre after <a href="German%20reunification">German reunification</a>, famous for its nightlife centered on the <a href="Hackesche%20H%C3%B6fe">Hackesche Höfe</a> courtyard ensemble. The square is also served by several <a href="Berlin%20tram">tramway</a> and <a href="Night%20bus%20service">night bus</a> lines. A weekly market is still held every Thursday and Saturday.
